title: Closing the GAP's: Utilizing Good Agricultural Practices

tasks.task: Louisa and Jim prepare for a GAP certification audit by addressing worker hygiene and crop protection practices.
subtasks: Organize worker hygiene facilities, including outdoor toilets with plenty of TP, handwashing stations with large dispensers, and waste disposal.
Ensure workers wash hands after using toilets; post reminders and arrange deliveries with maintained sanitation.
Review and enhance crop protection agent storage and usage records, calibrating equipment regularly, maintaining proper intervals, and documenting worker safety.
Inspect and clean water sources and fixtures; update disaster plans for the nearby stream found contaminated.
Develop comprehensive training and hygiene policies, enforce strict protocols for sick employees and contaminated produce.
Transition to reliable shippers with adherence to strict pre-shipment checks for cleanliness and temperature control.
Address GAP requirements for compost, water testing, and traceability in product labeling for record-keeping and auditing readiness.
Establish farm policies for emergency situations, such as washroom disinfection in case of cuts or blood contact.

tasks.task: Excavate a new irrigation ditch to improve water drainage on a piece of land they wish to purchase.
subtasks: Hire professionals to assess the land’s capability and obtain necessary permits.
Arrange a timeline for construction, including mechanical and agricultural experts for soil preservation.
Organize a team for excavation with proper equipment and safety measures, ensuring minimal disruption to ongoing farming activities.
Monitor progress and address any unexpected issues during excavation, such as rock deposits or water supply considerations.
Test and clean the newly dug ditch, integrating erosion control and drainage solutions to prevent future water contamination.

tasks.task: Louisa and Jim conduct a detailed assessment of the neighboring land’s historical use prior to a potential purchase.
subtasks: Review public records for land use history of the adjacent plot for over 50 years to identify any contamination or misuse.
Confirm the land's suitability for food crop production by checking for industrial or non-food livestock uses in the past.
Secure legal title confirmation and verify compliance with local agricultural regulations and zoning laws.
Evaluate the neighbor’s current land use, identifying potential sources of contamination or pesticide drift (e.g., nearby dairy).
Implement fencing and other mitigation measures to prevent cross-contamination from neighboring lands (e.g., horse exclusion to halt chemical use drift).

tasks.task: Implement a composting and soil management plan in line with GAP standards to reduce microbial contamination.
subtasks: Source commercially tested and certified compost from reputable manufacturers.
Establish compost application records and tracking protocols for each field.
Verify adherence to GAP guidelines by testing and accepting only compost that meets pathogen-free standards.

tasks.task: Set up a comprehensive worker training program to adhere to GAP standards.
subtasks: Develop and document safety policies for hygiene, such as mandatory handwashing after breaks, using the bathroom, or handling food.
Institute protocols for workers with illnesses, reassigning them to non-food contact tasks and allowing only those cleared by a doctor to return.
Schedule recurring safety and sanitation refresher courses for all employees, maintaining detailed attendance and topic records.
Perform regular audits of adherence to hygiene policies, documenting findings and enacting corrective measures where necessary.

tasks.task: Upgrade existing storage units for crop protection agents to comply with GAP requirements.
subtasks: Remove all unneeded containers and chemicals, reorganizing remaining products by type and manufacturer.
Seal and lock all pesticide storage areas to prevent unauthorized access and ensure environmental safety.
Label all stored agents clearly with expiration dates, manufacturer information, and minimal residue intervals.
Develop sanitization schedules for storage units, including regular cleaning, deodorizing, and moisture control.

tasks.task: Install and manage rodent control measures according to GAP protocols.
subtasks: Deploy non-bait traps at recommended intervals across the farm.
Create a map of all trap locations for systematic monitoring and servicing.
Enforce a regular inspection and replacement schedule to ensure effective pest control and trap hygiene.

tasks.task: Configure packing and transportation areas to meet GAP standards.
subtasks: Sanitize washing and packing areas daily, using food-grade sanitizers and dust-proof covers.
Redesign storage racks to keep packing materials off the floor and away from chemicals.
Implement rodent-proof barriers around cold storage units and maintain consistent temperatures for produce quality and safety.

tasks.task: Establish a water testing regime in line with GAP best practices.
subtasks: Test water quality regularly, especially sources like the stream found contaminated, to ensure safety.
Update farm water usage policies to restrict use of contaminated water for edible portions and meticulously document test results.

tasks.task: Perform an excavation to create a new water drainage ditch in a field.
subtasks: Secure necessary permits and consult agriculture experts on soil preservation.
Engage excavation contractors with appropriate machinery and safety equipment.
Monitor excavation progress, ensuring no soil erosion or contamination occurs during the process.
Clean and inspect the completed ditch, integrating drainage controls such as tiles or berms to manage water flow effectively.
